title: Lesson 8 - Have, Exist or Not Have; May, Meron, Wala

contents.markdown: _May_ and _meron_ roughly mean “have” or “exist”. These are negated with _wala_, which roughly means not have or not exist. Anything you can express with may you can also express with meron, but they use different grammar. _Wala_ uses the same grammar as meron. If you do not know them, or need a refresher, please go to **Appendix A** and memorize _sa_ form noun markers.
<u>May</u>
_May_ means “have” or “exist” and is more common than its short form _me_, so we will use only may from now on. It needs to come immediately before an object.
May + \*\*object\*\*+ possessor/location. (Tag.) = Possessor has object/There is object in location. (Eng.)
**Notes: Possessor takes _ang_ form, location takes _sa_ form.**

item.english: Do you have a car?
There is a student in the school.

item.tagalog: May tsokolate ba ang babae sa bahay mo?
item.english: Does the woman in your house have chocolate?

contents.markdown: Here are some possible positive responses:

item.english: Yes, I have a car.
Yes. There is a student in the school. (resp.)
Yes. The woman has chocolate.

contents.markdown: <u>Meron</u>
_Meron_ means “have” or “exist” and is more common than its long form _mayroon_, so we will use only _meron_ from now on. Unlike _may_, it does not need to come immediately before an object.
\*\*Meron\*\*+ linker + object + possessor/location. (Tag.) = Possessor has object/There is object in location. (Eng.)
**Notes: Possessor takes _ang_ form, location takes _sa_ form.**

item.english: Do you have a car?
There is a student in the school.

item.tagalog: Meron bang tsokolate ang babae sa bahay mo?
item.english: Does the woman in your house have chocolate?

contents.markdown: Here are some possible positive answers:

item.english: Yes, I have a car.

item.tagalog: Opo. Meron pong estudyante sa eskwelahan.
item.english: Yes. There is a student in the school. (resp.)
Yes. She has chocolate.

contents.markdown: It is also ok to just say:

item.english: I have/there is/etc.

contents.markdown: However, you cannot just state _may_, because _may_ requires an object. That is a major difference between _meron_ and _may_.
<u>Wala</u>

_Wala_ means “not have” or “not exist”, and is used to give negative statements or negative answers to _may/meron_ questions. _Wala_ uses the same grammar as _meron_ and it does not need to come before an object.
\*\*Wala\*\*+ linker + object + possessor/location. (Tag.) = Possessor does not have object/There is no object in location. (Eng.)
**Notes: Possessor takes _ang_ form, location takes _sa_ form.**

item.english: You do not have a car.
There are no students in the school.
She has no chocolate.

contents.markdown: It is also ok to just say:

item.english: There are none/you do not have/etc.

contents.markdown: <u>Ang May/Walang</u>
If you put _ang_ before _may/walang_ it means roughly “the one who has/does not have”. _Ang merong_ also works, but it is less common, so we will not use it.
ang + may/walang + noun (Tag.) = the one who/that has/does not have (Eng.)

item.english: the one who has a car
the one without water
The one without money is not happy.

contents.markdown: <u>More on Sa Form of Nouns and Personal Pronouns </u>
The _sa_ form of a name or personal pronoun often implies “to someone”. But it can also mean “with someone”, and in the case of plural names or pps, “at someone’s place”, depending on the context.

item.english: to Maria or with Maria
to him/her or with him/her
to Joaquin and Joshua, with Joaquin and Joshua or at Joaquin and Joshua’s
to them, with them or at their place

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sino ang may pera sa kanila?
exampleSentences.english: Who has money at their place?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Meron po ba kayong tunay na puting adobo?
exampleSentences.english: Do you have real white adobo? (resp.)(meron)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Walang pera ang lalaki sa bahay niya.
exampleSentences.english: The man at her house has no money.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi ako ang may bahay sa Parañaque.
exampleSentences.english: I am not the one with a house in Parañaque.
The ones with chocolate are happy.

exampleSentences.tagalog: May pagod na mga estudyante sa amin.
exampleSentences.english: There are tired students at our (excl.) place.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Opo. Meron pong tubig sina Maria at Angel.
exampleSentences.english: Yes. Maria and Angel have water. (resp.)(meron)
